Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Assessment for Area of Study 1 (Religion and Ethics): one religion chosen from 1A Catholic Christianity, 1B Christianity, 1C Islam, 1D Buddhism, 1E Hinduism, 1F Judaism, 1G Sikhism. Must study all four content sections for the chosen religion: (1) Beliefs, (2) Marriage and the Family, (3) Living the Religious Life, (4) Matters of Life and Death. Written exam 1h45, 102 marks, 50% of GCSE. Four questions (a–d) covering the four sections; includes short open, open response and extended writing. Minimum 5% of marks assess spelling, punctuation and grammar and use of specialist terminology (SPaG). Students must answer all questions for the chosen religion.

Students study two Areas of Study from three (1, 2, 3) and must select a different religion for each Area of Study. If Catholic Christianity is selected for one Area of Study, Christianity cannot be selected for the second Area of Study (and vice versa).

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Understand the nature and significance of the Trinity as expressed in the Nicene Creed: oneness of God; distinct Persons (Father, Son, Holy Spirit); how Trinitarian belief is reflected in Catholic worship and belief and shapes Catholic life today.

Understand biblical understandings of God as a Trinity of Persons with reference to Jesus’ baptism (Matthew 3:13–17). Know the historical development of the doctrine of the Trinity including the First Council of Nicaea and the First Council of Constantinople.

Understand the nature and significance of the biblical account of Creation (Genesis 1–3) and divergent Christian ways of understanding it (literal and metaphorical). Explain significance of Creation for Catholics’ understanding of God’s nature/characteristics (Creator, benevolent, omnipotent, eternal).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Humanity in the image of God; stewardship vs dominion
Sub_topics.description: Understand significance of Creation for understanding humanity as created in the image of God (Genesis 1–3). Compare divergent Christian understandings of humanity’s relationship with Creation (dominion and stewardship) and implications for Catholics today (moral responsibility, environmental ethics).

Understand Catholic belief in the Incarnation: Jesus as incarnate Son/divine Word, fully God and fully human. Know scriptural origins (John 1:1–18) and why the Incarnation is important for Catholics today (revelation of God, salvation, model for life).

Understand events in the Paschal Mystery: Jesus’ life, death, resurrection, ascension with reference to Luke 24. Explain Catholic teaching on the redemptive efficacy of these events and their significance for Catholics today.

Understand significance of Jesus’ life/death/resurrection/ascension for Catholic beliefs about salvation and grace, including John 3:10–21 and Acts 4:8–12. Apply to implications for Catholic practice today (sacraments, moral life, evangelisation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eschatology and life after death (John 11:17–27; 2 Corinthians 5:1–10)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic beliefs about eschatology: resurrection, judgement, heaven, hell, purgatory, life after death; references: John 11:17–27 and 2 Corinthians 5:1–10. Compare divergent Christian beliefs about purgatory and the nature of resurrection. Explain why belief in life after death is important for Catholics today.

Understand Catholic teaching on the importance and purpose of marriage in Catholic life, including Not Just Good, But Beautiful (Pope Francis). Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes to marriage (sanctity, lack of importance, cohabitation) and Catholic responses.

Understand Catholic teaching on sexual relationships as marital, unitive, procreative (Catechism of the Catholic Church 2360–2365). Know Catholic teaching on sex outside marriage and same-sex sexual relationships. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes including acceptance of sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships, and Catholic responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Family purpose; types of family (Familiaris Consortio)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teaching on purpose and importance of family: procreation, security, education of children; Catholic responses to 21st-century family forms (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended) including Familiaris Consortio 36–85.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parish support for families (Family Group Movement; CCC 2226)
Sub_topics.description: Understand how/why the local Catholic parish supports families: family worship, sacraments, parent classes, children’s groups, counselling; reference Family Group Movement and Catechism of the Catholic Church 2226. Explain importance of parish support for Catholic families today.

Understand Catholic teaching on regulation of births: artificial contraception vs natural family planning, including Humanae Vitae. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes (including Protestant acceptance of contraception) and application of ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Catholic responses.

Understand Catholic teaching on divorce, annulment and remarriage including Catechism of the Catholic Church 2382–2386. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes including situation ethics approaches; explain Catholic responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality of men and women in the family (CCC 2207)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teaching on equality of men and women in the family with reference to Catechism of the Catholic Church 2207, including dignity of work within the home. Compare divergent Christian teachings/attitudes on equality and roles of men and women in family life and Catholic responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gender prejudice and discrimination (theology of the body; CCC 1938)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic opposition to gender prejudice and discrimination including theology of the body. Use examples such as Catechism of the Catholic Church 1938. Compare divergent Christian attitudes (including role of women in the Church) and explain Catholic responses to prejudice/discrimination.

Understand Catholic teaching on sacramental nature of reality (creation manifests God). Know the seven sacraments: meaning/effects (CCC 1210–1211), practice and symbolism, how sacraments communicate grace. Compare divergent Christian attitudes to sacraments (Orthodox and Protestant).

Understand nature and significance of the Mass for Catholics: structure; Eucharist as ‘source and summit of Christian life’ (Lumen Gentium paragraph 7). Compare divergent Christian attitudes to liturgical worship, including less structured worship in evangelical denominations.

Understand funeral rite as a liturgical celebration: practices at home, church, cemetery; reference ‘Preparing my funeral’ (Vincent Nichols). Explain aims: communion with deceased, communion of community, proclamation of eternal life; significance for Catholics.

Understand prayer as ‘raising of hearts and minds to God’: types of prayer; Lord’s Prayer (Matthew 6:5–14); set/formulaic prayers and informal/extempore prayer; when/why used; importance of prayer and having different types of worship for Catholics.

Understand nature/significance of popular piety: Rosary, Eucharistic adoration, Stations of the Cross; how/why used; importance of different types of worship (CCC 1674–1676). Compare divergent Christian attitudes to these devotions.

Understand nature/history/purpose of Catholic pilgrimage; significance of pilgrimage places. Compare divergent Christian views on importance of pilgrimage today; apply to Jerusalem, Lourdes, Rome, Walsingham with reference to CCC 2691–2696.

Understand Catholic Social Teaching as love of neighbour; teaching on justice, peace, reconciliation; Evangelii Gaudium 182–237 (inclusion of the poor). Apply to individual Catholic life using Matthew 25:31–46 (Sheep and Goats). Know CAFOD’s work: what it does and why.

Understand history/significance of Catholic mission and evangelism; divergent ways practiced locally/nationally/globally; how it fulfils Jesus’ commission and Church teaching, including Evangelii Gaudium Chapter 5.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins and value of the universe; science and Lemaître
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teaching on origins and value of universe: scientific explanations (e.g., Big Bang) and Catholic responses including Georges Lemaître. Explain value of universe in Catholic teaching and divergent Christian responses to viewing universe as commodity; use interpretations of Genesis 1–2.

Understand Catholic teaching on sanctity of life: why human life is holy; biblical interpretation supporting special status of life (created in image of God, Genesis 1–3). Explain importance of sanctity of life for Catholics today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins/value of human life: evolution and Catholic responses
Sub_topics.description: Understand scientific and non-religious explanations for origins/value of human life (evolution, survival of the fittest) and Catholic responses, including Pope Francis statement (27 Oct 2014, Pontifical Academy of Sciences) on evolution. Explain significance for Catholics today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Abortion: teachings and debates; ethical theories
Sub_topics.description: Understand nature of abortion; Catholic/Church teaching about abortion (including reference to Humanae Vitae). Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) pro-life and pro-choice arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Catholic responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death: support for belief (Ephesians 2:1–10)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teachings supporting belief in life after death including Ephesians 2:1–10. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious arguments for life after death (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones). Explain significance for Catholics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arguments against life after death and Catholic rebuttals (1 Peter 3:18–22)
Sub_topics.description: Understand non-religious arguments against life after death (comfort, lack of evidence, fraudulent accounts, social control) and why Catholics reject them, including reference to 1 Peter 3:18–22.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Euthanasia: teachings, hospice care, ethical theories (CCC 2276–2279)
Sub_topics.description: Understand nature of euthanasia; Catholic teaching including CCC 2276–2279 and support for hospice care. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Catholic responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural world ethics: environment and animals (CCC 2415–2418; utilitarianism)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic responses to threats to natural world (pollution, global warming, natural resources) including stewardship. Know differing Catholic responses to animal rights, animal experimentation, and use of animals for food with reference to CCC 2415–2418 and application of ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian belief in the Trinity: expressed in Nicene Creed; oneness of God; significance of Father, Son, Holy Spirit; include Matthew 3:13–17. Explain how Trinitarian belief is reflected in Christian worship and belief today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Creation of universe and humanity (Genesis 1–3; John 1:1–18)
Sub_topics.description: Understand biblical account of creation and divergent Christian interpretations (literal/metaphorical). Understand role of Word and Spirit in creation with reference to John 1:1–18 and Genesis 1–3. Explain importance of creation for Christians today.
Understand Incarnation: Jesus Christ as incarnate Son of God; biblical basis John 1:1–18 and 1 Timothy 3:16; significance for Christians today.
Understand Last Supper, betrayal, arrest, trial, crucifixion, resurrection, ascension; biblical accounts Luke 22–24; significance for understanding Jesus’ person.
Understand salvation: law, sin, grace, Spirit; role of Christ in salvation (John 3:10–21; Acts 4:8–12). Understand nature/significance of atonement and its link to salvation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eschatology and life after death (2 Corinthians 5:1–10; 39 Articles; Catholic teaching)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Christian teachings about life after death: resurrection, judgement, heaven, hell, purgatory; include 39 Articles of Religion and Catholic teachings. Use Bible reference 2 Corinthians 5:1–10. Explain divergent reasons beliefs are important for Christians today.

Understand problem of evil/suffering for belief in a loving and righteous God; issues for God’s nature (omniscience/omnipotence/benevolence as applicable, Psalm 103). Explain how problem may cause faith questioning or rejection. Distinguish natural suffering vs moral suffering with examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Responses to suffering (Psalm 119; Job; free will; soul-making; prayer; charity)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Christian solutions to problem of evil/suffering: biblical, theoretical, practical; references Psalm 119 and Job; ideas of free will; vale of soul-making; prayer and charity. Evaluate success/limits of these solutions.

Understand Christian teachings on importance/purpose of marriage, including Mark 10:6–9. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes: sanctity, lack of importance, cohabitation; explain Christian responses.

Understand divergent Christian teachings on sexual relationships; attitudes to sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships; include interpretations of 1 Corinthians 6:7–20. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious attitudes including acceptance of sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships; explain Christian responses.

Understand Christian teaching on family: procreation, security, education of children with reference to Ephesians 6:1–4. Understand divergent Christian responses to 21st-century families (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended).

Understand how/why local church supports families: family worship (Matthew 19:13–14), rites of passage, parent classes, counselling, children’s groups/Sunday schools; importance of parish support for Christians today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contraception and family planning (Humanae Vitae; situation ethics)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Christian attitudes to contraception/family planning: Protestant acceptance vs Catholic rejection with reference to Humanae Vitae. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Christian responses.

Understand Christian teachings on divorce/remarriage including Matthew 19:1–12. Compare divergent Christian and non-religious attitudes; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Christian responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality and gender roles in family (Genesis 1–3; Ephesians 5:21–30)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian teachings/attitudes about equality and roles of men and women in family life with reference to Genesis 1–3 and Ephesians 5:21–30. Compare divergent Christian views and responses.

Understand Christian opposition to gender prejudice and discrimination including Galatians 3:23–29; know examples of Christian opposition; understand divergent Christian attitudes (e.g., women’s role in Church) and responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Worship: liturgical and non-liturgical (Book of Common Prayer)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian worship: liturgical and non-liturgical forms including informal/individual activities; reference Book of Common Prayer. Explain when/why each used. Compare divergent Christian attitudes to meaning/significance, including less structured Pentecostal worship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sacraments/ordinances: baptism and Eucharist in two denominations (39 Articles XXV–XXXVI)
Sub_topics.description: Understand role of sacraments/ordinances in Christian life; detailed study of baptism and Eucharist meaning and celebration in at least two denominations; reference 39 Articles XXV–XXXVI. Compare divergent Christian attitudes to number/use of sacraments across Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant traditions.
Understand nature/purpose of prayer; types: set prayers, informal prayer, Lord’s Prayer (Matthew 6:5–14); when/why used; compare divergent Christian attitudes to importance of each type.

Understand nature/history/purpose of pilgrimage with interpretations of Luke 2:41–43. Explain significance of pilgrimage places; compare Catholic and Protestant views; know activities and significance of Jerusalem, Iona, Taizé, Walsingham.

Understand nature/history of festivals in church year: Christmas and Easter. Explain significance of Advent and Christmas; significance of Holy Week and Easter with reference to 1 Corinthians 15:12–34.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Future of the Church: mission and evangelism (Mark 16:9–20; John 20:21–22)
Sub_topics.description: Understand church growth and purpose/history of missionary/evangelical work (Mark 16:9–20; John 20:21–22). Compare divergent local/national/global practices; explain why evangelism matters for Church and individuals.

Understand role/importance of local church for individuals and local area: parish activities; interpretations of 1 Peter 5:1–4; ecumenism; outreach; church as centre of Christian identity and worship through lived practices.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Worldwide Church: charity and persecution; Christian Aid (1 Corinthians 13; Matthew 25:31–46)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Church role worldwide: reconciliation and issues of persecuted Church. Compare Christian responses to charity teachings (1 Corinthians 13; Matthew 25:31–46). Know Christian Aid: what it does and why.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins and value of universe; science and Lemaître; stewardship (Genesis 1–2)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian responses to scientific explanations of universe origins including Georges Lemaître; value of universe in Christian teaching; responses to treating universe as commodity; use Genesis 1–2 interpretations.
Understand Christian sanctity of life: why life is holy; Bible support (image of God, Genesis 1–3); importance for Christians today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins/value of human life: evolution and Christian responses
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian responses to scientific/non-religious accounts of human origins/value (evolution, survival of fittest), including Diocese of Manchester Special Agenda IV synod motions on compatibility of science and Christian belief; significance for Christians.

Understand nature of abortion; divergent Christian pro-life/pro-choice teachings (including Humanae Vitae) and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Christian responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death: resurrection and Ephesians 2:1–10; arguments for
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian belief supporting life after death: resurrection of Jesus and Ephesians 2:1–10. Compare arguments for life after death (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones). Explain significance for Christians.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arguments against life after death and Christian rebuttals (1 Peter 3:18–22)
Sub_topics.description: Understand non-religious arguments against afterlife and why Christians reject them (comfort, lack of evidence, fraud, social control) with reference to 1 Peter 3:18–22.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Euthanasia: teachings, hospice care; Job 2:1–10; ethical theories
Sub_topics.description: Understand nature of euthanasia; divergent Christian teachings and responses including support for hospice care and interpretations of Job 2:1–10. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Christian responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural world ethics: environment and animals (Assisi 1986; utilitarianism)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian responses to environmental threats: pollution, global warming, resources; stewardship; The Christian Declaration on Nature (Assisi 1986). Compare differing Christian responses to animal rights/experimentation/food using ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Understand the Six Beliefs of Islam: nature, history, purpose (Kitab al-iman 1:4). Explain how they are understood/expressed in Sunni and Shi’a communities and why they are important for Muslims.

Understand Shi’a Five Roots (Usul ad-Din): Tawhid, ‘Adl (Divine Justice), Nubuwwah, Imamah, Mi’ad. Know Qur’anic basis including Surah 112. Explain importance for different Shi’a communities (Sevener and Twelver).

Understand characteristics of Allah as shown in Qur’an and their importance: Tawhid/oneness (Surah 16:35–36), immanence, transcendence, omnipotence, beneficence, mercy, fairness/justice; include Adalat in Shi’a Islam.
Understand prophethood (Risalah): nature and importance (Surah 2:136). Know roles of prophets and what they teach, exemplified by Adam, Ibrahim, Isma’il, Musa, Dawud, Isa, Muhammad.

Understand nature/history/significance/purpose of Muslim holy books: Qur’an; Tawrat (Surah 5:43–48); Zabur (Surah 4:163–171); Injil (Surah 57:27); Sahifah (Scrolls). Understand divergent Muslim views on importance of these books today.
Understand nature/importance of angels; know Jibril, Izra’il, Mika’il as shown in Qur’an (Surah 32:11; 2:97–98) and significance for Muslims today.

Understand al-Qadr: nature/importance of predestination; relation to human freedom and Day of Judgement (Sahih al-Bukhari 78:685). Compare Sunni and Shi’a understandings; explain implications for Muslims today.
Understand Muslim teachings on Akhirah: judgement, paradise, hell; Qur’anic teaching (Surah 17:49–72). Explain divergent ways afterlife beliefs affect Muslim life today.

Understand importance/purpose of marriage in Muslim life; teachings including Surah 4:1–24, 24:30–34, 53:4–18. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes to marriage (lack of importance, cohabitation) and Muslim responses.

Understand divergent Muslim teachings on sexual relationships fulfilling physical, emotional, spiritual needs. Know teaching on sex outside marriage (Surah 23:5–11) and same-sex relationships. Compare non-religious attitudes (acceptance) and Muslim responses.

Understand Muslim teaching on family purpose: procreation, strengthening ummah; Surah 46:15–18. Understand divergent Muslim responses to 21st-century family types (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended).

Understand how/why ummah supports families: worship, rites of passage, parent classes, children’s groups, counselling. Explain divergent views on importance of such support and how it strengthens ummah; reference Surah 3:102–105.

Understand divergent Muslim teachings on contraception/family planning with reference to Sahih al-Bukhari 34:432 and 62:136. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Muslim responses.

Understand divergent Muslim beliefs/teachings about divorce/remarriage including Surah 2:226–241; know different rules for performing divorce in Sunni and Shi’a Islam. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Muslim responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality of men and women in family (Surah 4 context)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Muslim beliefs/teachings/attitudes on role of men and women in family with reference to Qur’an including Surah 4 and historical context (time of Muhammad).
Understand Muslim attitudes to gender prejudice and discrimination including Surah 33:35; know examples of gender equality in action in Islam.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ten Obligatory Acts (Shi’a) and relation to Five Pillars
Sub_topics.description: Understand Ten Obligatory Acts in Shi’a Islam: nature/history/purpose; diversity of practice and importance; Qur’anic basis Surah 9:71–73. Compare divergent understandings within Sunni Islam and links to Five Pillars.
Understand Shahadah as pillar: nature/role/significance for Sunni and Shi’a; reference Surah 3:17–21. Explain why reciting Shahadah is important and its place in Muslim practice today.

Understand Salah: nature/history/significance/purpose; reference Surah 15:98–99 and 29:45. Know performance: wudu/ablution, times, direction (qiblah), movements and recitations; home/mosque and Jummah. Understand Sunni/Shi’a similarities and differences.

Understand fasting (Sawm) in Ramadan: nature/role/significance/purpose; Surah 2:183–185. Know exemptions and reasons. Understand Night of Power (Laylat al-Qadr): nature/history/purpose and importance for Muslims.
Understand Zakah and Khums: nature/role/significance/purpose; Surah 9:58–60 and 8:36–42. Explain why Zakah is important for Sunni; why Khums is important for Shi’a; benefits for recipients.
Understand Hajj: nature/role/origins/significance; Surah 2:124–130 and 22:25–30. Know how Hajj is performed and why important; benefits and challenges for Muslims.

Understand Jihad: origins, meaning, significance; distinguish greater vs lesser Jihad. Know conditions for declaration of lesser Jihad with reference Surah 2:190–194 and 22:39; explain importance in Muslim life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Festivals and commemorations: Id-ul-Adha, Id-ul-Fitr, Id-ul-Ghadeer, Ashura
Sub_topics.description: Understand nature/origins/activities/meaning/significance of: Id-ul-Adha (Surah 37:77–111); Id-ul-Fitr in Sunni Islam and its place within Shi’a Islam; Id-ul-Ghadeer with reference to Hadith and interpretation of Surah 5:3; Ashura in Shi’a Islam and its place within Sunni Islam.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins/value of universe; Qur’an and science (Surah 67:1–5)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Muslim teachings about origins/value of universe: scientific explanations and Muslim responses including Surah 67:1–5; compatibility of Qur’an and science. Understand divergent Muslim teachings about value of universe and views on universe as commodity.
Understand Muslim teaching on sanctity of life: why life is holy; Qur’anic teaching Surah 5:32 and 4:29; divergent understandings of importance for Muslims today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human origins/value: evolution and Muslim responses (Surah 32:4–10; 21:30–33)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Muslim responses to scientific/non-religious explanations of human origins/value (evolution, survival of fittest) with interpretations of Surah 32:4–10 and 21:30–33; explain significance for Muslims today.

Understand divergent Muslim teachings on abortion: nature/use, including ensoulment and Sahih al-Bukhari 55:549. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Muslim responses.

Understand Muslim teachings supporting afterlife with reference to Surah 28:60–80. Compare divergent Muslim responses to arguments for life after death (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones) and significance for Muslims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arguments against afterlife and Muslim rebuttals (Surah 45:22–37)
Sub_topics.description: Understand non-religious arguments against afterlife and why Muslims reject them; reference Surah 45:22–37; include comfort, lack of evidence, fraudulent accounts, social control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Euthanasia: teachings and hospice; ethical theories (Surah 2:153–156)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Muslim teachings about euthanasia: nature/use; compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Muslim responses with Surah 2:153–156 and support for hospice care.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural world ethics: khalifah, animals (Sahih al-Bukhari 45:656; utilitarianism)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Muslim responses to environmental threats (pollution, global warming, resource use): stewardship and role as khalifah. Compare divergent Muslim responses to animal rights/experimentation/food, including Sahih al-Bukhari 45:656 and application of ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Sub_topics.description: Understand key events in Buddha’s life and why important today: ancestry, birth, princely life, marriage, Four Sights (Buddhavamsa XXVI); enlightenment; founding of Sangha.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dhamma: dependent origination and Three Marks (Milinda Panha)
Sub_topics.description: Understand dhamma meanings: dependent origination/conditionality (paticca-samuppada) and Three Marks of Existence. Use Story of Nagasena and the Chariot (Milinda Panha) to explain anicca (impermanence), dukkha (suffering), anatta (no fixed self). Explain implications for Buddhists today.
Understand First Noble Truth with reference to Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta: nature of dukkha; types of suffering (pain, fabrication, change); importance for Buddhists today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Second Noble Truth: tanha and Three Poisons; Wheel of Life
Sub_topics.description: Understand Second Noble Truth (Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta): samudaya (root of suffering), causes of suffering (Sermon at Benares), Three Poisons and representation in Wheel of Life. Understand divergent understandings of Wheel of Life in Theravada vs Mahayana.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Third Noble Truth: cessation; samsara; nibbana/enlightenment
Sub_topics.description: Understand Third Noble Truth (Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta): nirodha, cessation of tanha; nature of samsara cycle; different understandings of nibbana and enlightenment; importance for Buddhists today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fourth Noble Truth: Eightfold Path; Threefold Way
Sub_topics.description: Understand Fourth Noble Truth (Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta): Middle Way (magga) and Eightfold Path to nibbana. Understand Threefold Way: sila (ethics), samadhi (meditation), panna (wisdom); divergent understandings of importance of Eightfold Path/Threefold Way today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human life and ultimate ideals (khandhas; Buddha-nature; Pure Land)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Buddhist teachings on human life: Five Khandas (Khandha Sutta); sunnata (emptiness) and tathagatagarbha (Buddha-nature); Arahant and Bodhisattva ideals; Buddhahood and Pure Land; how traditions differ (Theravada/Mahayana).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ethics: kamma, rebirth, compassion, precepts, perfections
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Buddhist ethical teachings and applications: kamma (Dhammapada 181–187; Khuddakapatha), merit and rebirth, karuna (compassion), metta (loving kindness), pancha sila (Five Precepts), paramitas (Six Perfections); how applied in Buddhist life today.

Understand divergent Buddhist views on importance/purpose of marriage; teachings including Sigalovada Sutta and possible ideal of celibacy. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes (lack of importance, cohabitation) and Buddhist responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sexual relationships and Third Precept (Cunda Kammaraputta Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist teaching on sexual relationships: Third Precept; Cunda Kammaraputta Sutta. Understand attitudes to celibacy (e.g., Jodo Shinshu monks). Understand divergent Buddhist attitudes to sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships; compare non-religious attitudes and Buddhist responses.

Understand Buddhist teachings about purpose/importance of family (Sigalovada Sutta) and responses to different family types in 21st century (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended).

Understand role of sangha as refuge (Khuddakapatha 1) and how/why community supports families through worship, rites of passage, festivals, counselling; divergent understandings of importance of support for Buddhists today.

Understand divergent Buddhist attitudes to contraception/family planning with reference to The Natural World (XIV Dalai Lama). Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Buddhist responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divorce and remarriage (Ven. K. Sri Dhammananda)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Buddhist beliefs/attitudes to divorce/remarriage including A Happy Married Life: A Buddhist Perspective (Ven. K. Sri Dhammananda). Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Buddhist responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Equality of men and women in family (Buddha; Sigalovada Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Buddhist teachings on equality/roles of men and women in family with reference to Buddha’s life and Sigalovada Sutta.
Understand Buddhist opposition to gender prejudice/discrimination including Soma Sutta; know examples of gender equality in action in Buddhism.

Understand meditation in Buddhism: purpose/significance; samatha, metta bhavana, vipassana; practices including mindfulness breathing and zazen; divergent understandings of visualisation of Buddha/Bodhisattvas (Amitāyus Meditation Sutra); differences in Mahayana vs Theravada use; benefits of meditation.
Understand chanting: devotional practice and mental concentration; Dhammapada 1–2 (confidence/joy). Compare importance in Theravada (Tiratana; Dhammapada 190) vs Mahayana (Nam Myoho Renge Kyo).
Understand nature/purpose/role/importance of mantra recitation in Theravada (Namo Buddhaya) and Mahayana; use of sacred syllables, offerings, mala beads; reasons for variation between schools.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Places of worship: temples, gompas, viharas, shrines (Kimsila Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent nature/history/design of Buddhist worship places (temples, gompas, viharas, shrines) across Theravada, Mahayana, Triratna. How/why used: shrine room, shrine facing east, library and importance of learning (Kimsila Sutta).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Objects of devotion (buddharupas; Bodhi tree; Vakkali Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand how/why objects of devotion are used: buddharupas, shrine, Bodhi tree; reference Vakkali Sutta. Understand divergent views on importance of devotional objects today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Puja in home and vihara (Mangala Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand nature/purpose of puja in vihara and home; reference Mangala Sutta. Know examples of types of puja, when/why used; importance of different types of worship in different Buddhist contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death and mourning rituals (Tibetan Book of the Dead)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent death/mourning rituals and their significance; distinctions between Theravada communities and Japan/Tibet; reference Tibetan Book of the Dead.

Understand divergent nature/history/purpose/importance of festivals/retreats: Wesak; Vassa/Rain Retreat; Kathina (Anapanasati Sutta); Uposatha days (Theravada); Hanamatsuri and Obon (Japanese); Parinibbana Day (Mahayana); Lama Tsong Khapa Day (Tibet).

Understand Buddhist responses to scientific origins of universe: origins may have no significance; reference The Universe in a Single Atom Chapter 4 (XIV Dalai Lama). Understand value of universe/natural world and divergent Buddhist responses to view of universe as commodity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sanctity of life and First Precept (Khuddakapatha)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist teaching on sanctity of life with reference to First Precept (Khuddakapatha): why life is special; divergent understandings of importance of life for Buddhists today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human origins/value: evolution and Buddhist responses (Cula-Malunkyovada Sutta)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist responses to scientific/non-religious explanations of human origins/value (evolution, survival of fittest) with interpretations of Cula-Malunkyovada Sutta; divergent views on significance for Buddhists today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Abortion and First Precept (Dalai Lama interview)
Sub_topics.description: Understand implications of Buddhist teaching for abortion: divergent teachings; First Precept; New York Times Interview with the Dalai Lama (5 Dec 1993). Compare non-religious arguments; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Buddhist responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death and afterlife: Wheel of Life and impermanence (Divyavadana 21)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist beliefs supporting life after death: Wheel of Life; impermanence of self; reference Sahasodgata Avadana, Divyavadana 21. Compare responses to arguments for afterlife (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones); significance for Buddhists.
Understand why Buddhists reject arguments against life after death (comfort, lack of evidence, fraud, social control) with reference to Brahmajala Sutta 4.

Understand Buddhist teaching on euthanasia including Vakkali Sutta. Compare non-religious arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Buddhist responses including support for hospice care (Buddhist Hospice Trust).

Understand Buddhist responses to environmental threats; teachings including Dhammapada 270 and The Buddhist Declaration on Nature (Assisi 1986). Compare responses to animal rights/experimentation/food using ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Understand nature of Brahman as spirit/ultimate reality/absolute truth; characteristics as shown in scripture including Katha Upanishad 2.2.6–8.

Understand Nirguna Brahman and Saguna Brahman: scriptural examples Nirguna (Taittiriya Upanishad 2.7.1–2) and Saguna (Rig Veda 1.154.1–2). Understand Vaikuntha (spiritual worlds). Explain divergent expressions of these beliefs in Hindu life today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Three aspects of the divine: Brahman/Antaryami/Bhagavan (Mundaka Upanishad 2.1)
Sub_topics.description: Understand three aspects of the divine: Brahman (everywhere, non-personal), Antaryami (within the heart), Bhagavan (beyond, personal loving God). Use Mundaka Upanishad 2.1. Explain importance for Hindu life and religious pluralism today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deities, avatars, murti; Vishnu/Shiva; Shakti (Rig Veda 1.22)
Sub_topics.description: Understand manifestations of the divine: deities in scripture; avatars and murti. Understand male deities and divergent importance of Vishnu (Rig Veda 1.22) and Shiva; understand female force Shakti including Parvati and Lakshmi.

Understand nature/importance of atman (eternal self), karma, samsara cycle, moksha. Use Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4; understand divergent Hindu interpretations. Explain why these beliefs matter for Hindus today.

Understand purpose of human life: four aims (Purusharthas)—dharma, artha, kama, moksha. Understand sanatana dharma (eternal law) including Bhagavad Gita 3.35; understand varnashrama dharma (duties by material situation/stage of life).

Understand Hindu responses to suffering, knowledge and ignorance: ahimsa, respect, empathy, mind/sense control, humility, love; Mahabharata 5.39. Understand divergent Hindu explanations of suffering/ignorance and relevance today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cosmology: yugas, prakriti, tri-guna, maya (Rig Veda 10.129)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu cosmology: creation/cosmic questions in Rig Veda 10.129; cycle of four ages (yugas) including Kali Yuga (Mahabharata); many worlds and beings; concepts of prakriti, tri-guna, maya; divergent understandings and significance.

Understand Hindu teaching on importance/purpose of marriage, including Rig Veda 10.85.36–47. Compare divergent Hindu and non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes (lack of importance, cohabitation) and Hindu responses.

Understand Hindu teachings on sexual relationships with interpretations of Bhagavad Gita 5.21–23; divergent attitudes to sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships. Compare non-religious attitudes and Hindu responses.

Understand Hindu teaching on family: procreation, security, education of children; Bhagavad Gita 1.37–43. Understand responses to modern family types (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended).
Understand how/why local Hindu community supports families (Bhagavad Gita 1.37–43): worship, rites of passage, festivals, counselling; importance of support for Hindu families today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Family planning and householder stage (Bhagavad Gita 3.37–43)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Hindu attitudes to contraception/family planning; reference householder stage and Bhagavad Gita 3.37–43. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Hindu responses.

Understand Hindu attitudes to divorce/remarriage including Hindu Marriage Act 1955 (India) and arguments supporting or rejecting divorce. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Hindu responses.
Understand Hindu teachings/attitudes on equality and roles of men and women in family life with reference to Manusmriti 3.55–60; understand divergent attitudes.
Understand Hindu opposition to gender prejudice/discrimination including interpretations of Bhagavad Gita 6.29–32; know examples of gender equality in action in Hinduism.
Understand Hindu yoga: karma yoga, jnana yoga, astanga/raja yoga, bhakti yoga; examples of use and reasons; importance of having different paths; Bhagavad Gita 6.44–47.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Focuses of worship and representations (Bhagavad Gita 6.20–31)
Sub_topics.description: Understand different focuses of worship: one God (personal/non-personal), many deities, gurus, holy places, sacred plants/animals; scriptural basis including Bhagavad Gita 6.20–31; importance of representations in worship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Places of worship: temple, home, outdoors, heart-space (Bhagavad Gita 9.13–27)
Sub_topics.description: Understand importance of different places of worship: temple, home, outside, shrines, festivals, heart-space; Bhagavad Gita 9.13–27; benefits of having different worship spaces.

Understand prayer/worship in temple and home: meditation, puja, havan, darshan, arti, bhajan, kirtan, japa; Bhagavad Gita 6.44–47. Understand when/why used and divergent views on benefits of different worship forms.

Understand nature/history/purpose/significance of Hindu festivals and origins/meaning of Diwali, Holi, Navratri Dussehra, Ram Navami, Ratha-yatra, Janmashtami, Raksha Bandhan; include interpretations of Brhadaranyaka Upanishad 1.3.28.

Understand nature/history/purpose of Hindu pilgrimage; significance of places; divergent views on importance today. Know pilgrimage to Ganges (Rig Veda 10.75), Vrindavana, Varanasi: features, history, importance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Environmental projects and sacred ecology (Rig Veda 10.87.16–19)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Hindu views on environmental care: importance of rivers/sacred places; how Hindus care for environment; examples including cow protection; Rig Veda 10.87.16–19.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charity and a named Hindu charity (Bhagavad Gita 3.10–12)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu teachings on charity: nature/purpose; know one named Hindu charity promoting wellbeing, social inclusion and women’s rights—what it does and why; Bhagavad Gita 3.10–12.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins/value of universe; science and Rig Veda 10.129
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu teachings on origins/value of universe: scientific explanations and Hindu responses including Rig Veda 10.129; compatibility of Hindu beliefs and science; value of universe; divergent responses to viewing universe as commodity.
Understand Hindu ideas about sanctity of life: why life might be holy; scriptural support including Katha Upanishad 1.3.3; importance for Hindus today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human origins/value: evolution and Rig Veda 10.129
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu responses to evolution/survival of fittest and significance for Hindus today, including interpretations of Rig Veda 10.129.

Understand nature of abortion; divergent Hindu teachings including interpretations of Atharva Veda 6.113. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Hindu responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death (Bhagavad Gita 4.23–30) and arguments for
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu teachings supporting life after death including Bhagavad Gita 4.23–30. Compare arguments for life after death (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones) and significance for Hindus.
Understand why Hindus reject arguments against life after death (comfort, lack of evidence, fraud, social control) including Bhagavad Gita 15.6–12.

Understand nature of euthanasia; Hindu teachings including Bhagavad Gita 7.25–30; compare divergent Hindu and non-religious arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Hindu responses including support for hospice care.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural world ethics (Assisi 1986; Bhagavad Gita 13.27–34; utilitarianism)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu responses to environmental threats; teachings including The Hindu Declaration on Nature (Assisi 1986) and Bhagavad Gita 13.27–34. Compare responses to animal rights/experimentation/food using ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.description: Understand characteristics of the Almighty in Torah and why important: One, Creator, Law-Giver, Judge; include reference to Genesis 2.

Understand Shekhinah (divine presence): how shown in Torah/scripture and why important, including interpretations of 2 Chronicles 7:1–3. Understand divergent understandings in different forms of Orthodox Judaism and importance today.

Understand nature/purpose of Messiah; scriptural basis Jeremiah 23:5–8. Understand Messianic Age and Jewish responsibility to bring it about. Compare divergent understandings in Orthodox vs Reform Judaism and importance today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covenant with Abraham (Genesis 17) and Promised Land
Sub_topics.description: Understand Abrahamic covenant: nature/history; Abraham’s role (Genesis 17). Explain why Promised Land covenant is important for Jews today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covenant at Sinai and Ten Commandments (Exodus 20)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Covenant at Sinai: Ten Commandments (Exodus 20) and Moses’ role/significance. Compare divergent understandings of importance of Decalogue in Jewish life today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sanctity of life and Pikuach Nefesh (Talmud Yoma 83–84)
Sub_topics.description: Understand why human life is holy; how life is special. Understand Pikuach Nefesh (primacy of life) with Talmud Yoma 83–84: life takes precedence over everything. Compare divergent applications by Jews today and reasons.

Understand nature/importance of Mitzvot with reference to Mishneh Torah of Maimonides: Sefer Madda. Understand relationship between keeping Mitzvot and free will; Mitzvot between humans and Almighty and between humans; divergent understandings of importance today.

Understand divergent Jewish beliefs about life after death in Orthodox and Reform Judaism. Use interpretations of Ecclesiastes 12; understand resurrection and judgement; explain why afterlife belief may be important for Jews today.
Understand Jewish teachings on marriage importance/purpose including Proverbs 18:22. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes (lack of importance, cohabitation) and Jewish responses.

Understand Jewish teaching on sexual relationships including Genesis 1:26–31 and Song of Songs. Understand divergent Jewish attitudes to sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships; compare non-religious attitudes and Jewish responses.

Understand Jewish teaching on family: procreation, security, education of children; Psalm 127:3–5. Compare divergent Jewish and non-religious responses to purpose of family and different types of family in 21st century.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Community support for families (Talmud Bava Batra 21a–b)
Sub_topics.description: Understand how/why Jewish community supports families: family worship, rites of passage, parent classes, children’s groups, counselling; reference Talmud Bava Batra 21a–b. Explain importance for Jews today.

Understand divergent Jewish teachings on contraception/family planning with reference to Talmud Yevamot 61b. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply ethical theories such as situation ethics; explain Jewish responses.

Understand divergent Jewish teachings on divorce/remarriage with reference to Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Ishut 24 and arguments supporting/rejecting divorce. Compare Jewish and non-religious attitudes (situation ethics) and Jewish responses.
Understand Jewish teachings on equality and roles of men and women in family with reference Genesis 1:26–31; understand divergent Jewish attitudes and responses.
Understand Jewish opposition to gender prejudice/discrimination including The Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty (1992, The Knesset). Know examples of gender equality in action in Judaism.
Understand Jewish public worship: nature, features, purpose with interpretations of Psalms 116:12–19. Understand synagogue services’ importance for community and individual.

Understand Tenakh (written law) and Talmud (oral law) significance in daily life; reference Perkei Avot 2. Understand food laws (kashrut): kosher/treifah, separation of meat and dairy; Deuteronomy 14:3–10. Understand divergent implications for Jews today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prayer at home and private prayer (Psalms 55:16–23)
Sub_topics.description: Understand prayer in home/private prayer: nature, features, purpose; prayer three times daily; importance of different forms of prayers; Psalms 55:16–23.
Understand nature/importance of Shema and Amidah (standing prayer): when used, how, why; include reference to mezuzah; Deuteronomy 6:4. Explain importance for Jews today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rituals: birth, coming of age, marriage; mourning
Sub_topics.description: Understand rituals: birth (including Brit Milah), Bar/Bat Mitzvah, marriage rituals; references Genesis 21:1–8, Genesis 17, Leviticus 12. Understand mourning rituals: funeral, shiva, avelut, yahrzeit. Compare divergent importance across Orthodox and Reform Judaism.
Understand nature/features/history/purpose of Shabbat in home and synagogue; Exodus 31:12–18. Explain why Shabbat is important for community and individual today.

Understand nature/history/purpose/significance of festivals: Rosh Hashanah, Yom Kippur, Pesach, Shavuot, Sukkot; include interpretations of Leviticus 23 (Rosh Hashanah). Compare divergent reasons festivals matter in Orthodox vs Reform Judaism.

Understand synagogue design differences (Liberal, Reform, Orthodox): facing Jerusalem, seating layout, Ark, bimah; Proverbs 14:28. Understand how/why synagogue is used; Exodus 27:20–21. Understand objects of devotion: yad, Torah scroll, ner tamid, menorah.
Understand Jewish teaching on origins/value of universe: scientific explanations and Jewish responses with Genesis 1–3; value of universe; divergent responses to viewing universe as commodity.
Understand Jewish teachings on value of life: image of Almighty in Genesis 1–3; divergent teachings; significance of sanctity of life for Jews today.
Understand Jewish responses to evolution/survival of fittest with Genesis 1:26–31; explain significance for Jews today.
Understand nature of abortion; divergent Jewish teachings including Mishnah Sanhedrin 4:5. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Jewish responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death (Maimonides’ 13 Principles) and arguments for
Sub_topics.description: Understand Jewish teachings supporting life after death including Maimonides’ Thirteen Principles of the Jewish Faith. Compare divergent Jewish arguments for life after death (remembered lives, paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones) and significance across traditions.
Understand non-religious arguments against afterlife and why Jews may reject them (comfort, lack of evidence, fraud, social control) with reference to Isaiah 25.

Understand nature of euthanasia; different Jewish teachings including interpretations of Judges 9:51–57. Compare Jewish and non-religious arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Jewish responses including support for hospice care.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural world ethics: stewardship (Psalm 24:1–3; Assisi 1986; utilitarianism)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Jewish responses to environmental threats: stewardship and humanity’s role; Psalm 24:1–3; The Jewish Declaration on Nature (Assisi 1986). Compare responses to animal rights/experimentation/food using ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 1: Religion and Ethics

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of God and Mool Mantar (GGS 1)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh belief in God’s nature as shown in Mool Mantar (Guru Granth Sahib 1): characteristics and why important; significance of Mool Mantar for Sikh identity and belief.
Understand God as Creator (Karta Purakh): nature and importance; teachings in Guru Granth Sahib 12 and 94.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purpose of human life: unite with God (GGS 12)
Sub_topics.description: Understand purpose/significance of human life as opportunity to unite with God; why uniting with God matters; how it affects Sikh lives; Guru Granth Sahib 12.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life after death: karma, rebirth, mukti (GGS 2; 11; 78)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh beliefs about life after death: karma, rebirth, mukti (liberation); references Guru Granth Sahib 2, 11, 78. Understand divergent views on importance and implications for Sikh life today.

Understand being gurmukh (God-centred) not manmukh (self-centred) and eliminating haumai (ego/pride); references Guru Granth Sahib 125 and 226. Know actions of gurmukh and divergent reasons for importance today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oneness of humanity and gender equality (GGS 349)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh teaching on equality of all humans (Guru Granth Sahib 349). Use stories from Gurus (e.g., Mai Bhago; women appointed as teachers). Explain how equality is shown in Sikh life today and why complete equality of men and women matters.

Understand sewa: tan, man, dhan; origins/purpose and importance in development of Sikhism (Guru Granth Sahib 26). Understand divergent practice and why sewa is central in reflecting priority of service.
Understand nature/history of sangat; why important (Guru Granth Sahib 1316). Understand concept of Sat Sangat and divergent significance; problems for Sikhs living without a sangat.
Understand Sikh teaching on marriage importance/purpose including the Lavan by Guru Ram Das. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) attitudes (lack of importance, cohabitation) and Sikh responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sexual relationships; same-sex relationships and authority (GGS 4; 2005 edict)
Sub_topics.description: Understand divergent Sikh teachings on sexual relationships; teaching on sex outside marriage and same-sex relationships; reference Guru Granth Sahib 4 and January 2005 edict of Jathedar of Akal Takht (Amritsar). Compare non-religious acceptance attitudes and Sikh responses.

Understand Sikh teachings on family purpose: procreation, security, education of children; references Guru Granth Sahib 71 and 599. Understand divergent Sikh responses to 21st-century family types (nuclear, single parent, same-sex parents, extended, blended).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Support in Sikh community and Rahit Maryada Ch.10
Sub_topics.description: Understand how/why Sikh community supports families: family worship, rites of passage, parent classes, children’s groups, counselling. Explain importance of support in sangat, with reference to Rahit Maryada Chapter 10.

Understand divergent Sikh teachings on contraception/family planning; reference concept of kaam and Sikh Missionary Society Introduction to Sikhism Section VII: Sikhism & Modern Problems Q124. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Sikh responses.

Understand divergent Sikh teachings on divorce/remarriage with reference to Rahit Maryada Chapter 11 and arguments supporting/rejecting divorce. Compare non-religious attitudes; apply situation ethics; explain Sikh responses.
Understand divergent Sikh teachings on roles of men and women in family life with reference to Guru Granth Sahib 788.
Understand Sikh teachings about gender prejudice/discrimination (Guru Granth Sahib 473) and examples of Sikh opposition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gurdwara features and objects (Rahit Maryada Ch.4–6)
Sub_topics.description: Understand gurdwara design as ‘Door/Gate of the Guru’ (Rahit Maryada Chapters 4–6). Know objects of devotion: Guru Granth Sahib, takht, chanani, chaur, langar hall, four doors, Nishan Sahib. Understand divergent views on importance today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role of gurdwara; Golden Temple visit (GGS 1391; GGS 4)
Sub_topics.description: Understand role/importance of gurdwara for Sikh community (Guru Granth Sahib 1391): activities and purposes. Understand significance of visiting historical gurdwaras, especially Harmandir Sahib (Golden Temple, Amritsar); divergent views; reference Guru Granth Sahib 4.
Understand history of langar (Guru Granth Sahib 967); nature and purposes; significance today as expression of sewa.
Understand Nam Japna (meditating on God’s name): nature/significance; diverse use in gurdwara and daily life; reference Guru Granth Sahib 1142.
Understand prayer in Sikhism (Guru Granth Sahib 305): nature/role/purpose in home; types of prayer; when/why prayer takes place; importance of having different prayers.

Understand akhand path: continuous 48-hour reading of Guru Granth Sahib; nature/history/role/purpose (Rahit Maryada Chapter 7). Explain how/why Sikhs participate and importance for community and individuals.

Understand nature/history/purpose of gurpurbs/commemorations and why important today. Know origins/meaning: Guru Nanak’s birthday; Vaisakhi with account in Gurbilas Patshahi 10. Understand Divali commemorations: martyrdom of Guru Arjan and Guru Tagh Bahadur Ji.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Naam Karan, Hukamnama, Amrit Sanskar; Singh/Kaur (Rahit Maryada Ch.11,13)
Sub_topics.description: Understand birth/naming rituals: Naam Karan and Hukamnama. Understand significance of Amrit Sanskar initiation for Sikh families (Rahit Maryada Chapters 11 and 13). Compare khalsa vs non-khalsa perspectives. Explain significance of names Singh and Kaur for identity.

Understand Sikh responses to scientific explanations of universe origins; compatibility of Sikh belief and science. Understand Sikh teachings about value of universe (Guru Granth Sahib 1037) and responses to treating universe as commodity.
Understand Sikh teaching on sanctity of life: why life is holy; Guru Granth Sahib 1239; divergent understandings of importance today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human origins: evolution and Sikh responses (GGS 19)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Sikh responses to evolution/survival of fittest with interpretations of Guru Granth Sahib 19; significance for Sikhs today.

Understand nature of abortion; Sikh teachings including Guru Granth Sahib 74 and debate on when life begins (e.g., conception). Compare non-religious arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Sikh responses.

Understand Sikh beliefs supporting life after death; compare responses to arguments for afterlife (remembered lives; possible interpretations of Guru Granth Sahib 19; paranormal, logic, reward, comfort, meeting loved ones) and significance for Sikhs.
Understand non-religious arguments against afterlife and why Sikhs reject them, including Guru Granth Sahib 430.

Understand nature/use of euthanasia; Sikh teaching including Lord Indarjit Singh’s House of Lords speech on Assisted Dying (12 Dec 2014). Compare non-religious arguments; apply situation ethics; explain Sikh responses including support for hospice care.

Understand Sikh responses to environmental threats (pollution, warming, resources) with Guru Granth Sahib 1037. Understand divergent Sikh responses to animal rights/experimentation/food and apply ethical theories such as utilitarianism.

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 2: Religion, Peace and Conflict

Sub_topics.description: Assessment for Area of Study 2 (Religion, Peace and Conflict): one religion chosen from 2A Catholic Christianity, 2B Christianity, 2C Islam, 2D Buddhism, 2E Hinduism, 2F Judaism, 2G Sikhism. Must study all four sections: (1) Beliefs, (2) Crime and Punishment, (3) Living the Religious Life, (4) Peace and Conflict. Written exam 1h45, 102 marks, 50% of GCSE. Four questions (a–d); includes short open, open response and extended writing; SPaG minimum 5%. Must answer all questions for chosen religion; religion must differ from the other Area of Study taken.

Students must study a different religion in their second Area of Study. If Catholic Christianity is selected for one Area of Study, Christianity cannot be selected for another Area of Study (and vice versa).

Topics.Strand: Area of Study 2: Religion, Peace and Conflict

Sub_topics.description: Beliefs content is identical to Area of Study 1A Section 1 Catholic Beliefs: Trinity (Nicene Creed), biblical Trinity (Matthew 3:13–17; Nicaea/Constantinople), Creation (Genesis 1–3; literal/metaphorical; God’s characteristics), humanity in image of God (dominion/stewardship), Incarnation (John 1:1–18), Paschal Mystery (Luke 24), salvation and grace (John 3:10–21; Acts 4:8–12), eschatology and life after death (John 11:17–27; 2 Corinthians 5:1–10; divergent Christian beliefs incl. purgatory).

Understand Catholic attitudes to justice: nature of justice; why important; biblical basis Micah 3:1–12. Understand Catholic reasons justice matters for victims. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) reasons for justice and Catholic responses.
Understand Catholic teaching on nature/causes/problem of crime with John 8:1–11. Know actions Catholic/Christian individuals and groups take to end crime, including Prison Fellowship.

Understand Catholic teaching on good actions and reward; evil actions. Compare non-religious (atheist/Humanist) views on why people suffer (including belief in religion) and Catholic responses. Understand divergent Christian views on suffering including Parable of Sheep and Goats (Matthew 25:31–46).

Understand nature of punishment; why important for Catholics; biblical teaching about punishment (Luke 12:35–48). Explain why punishment can be regarded as justice and why society might need punishment.
Understand Catholic attitudes to aims of punishment: protection, retribution, deterrence, reformation. Use biblical example Galatians 6:1–10 to support understanding.

Understand Catholic teaching on forgiveness: nature, biblical basis, and community forgiveness of offenders; why needed. Understand mercy and why important to show mercy to criminals; reference Matthew 5:21–26.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treatment of criminals: human rights and torture (Proverbs 31:8–9)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Catholic teaching on treatment of criminals: Proverbs 31:8–9; torture, human rights, fair trial, trial by jury. Compare divergent attitudes including situation ethics that may accept torture for greater good.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death penalty: debates and texts (Genesis 9:6; Exodus 21:8–13; Matthew 5:38–48)
Sub_topics.description: Understand capital punishment: nature/purpose; Catholic teaching; divergent Christian arguments for/against with Genesis 9:6, Exodus 21:8–13, Matthew 5:38–48. Understand revelation as proof of God: shown in Bible including covenants with Noah and Abraham, and through Jesus; Hebrews 1:1–4. Understand divergent interpretations of what revelation shows about God for Christians.

Understand visions: nature/importance; biblical and non-biblical examples including Genesis 15 and Matthew 17:1–13. Explain why visions may lead to belief and Christian responses to atheist/Humanist hallucination objections. Understand divergent views of what visions show about God.

Understand miracles: nature/importance; biblical examples including John 4:43–54. Explain why miracles may lead to belief and Christian responses to atheist/Humanist scientific explanation objections; divergent views on what miracles show about God.
Understand religious experience: nature and why it might be regarded as revelation including Exodus 3. Explain Christian responses to atheist/Humanist claims that experiences are not proof of God.
Understand Christian teachings on prayer: nature/importance. Explain why answered prayer might lead to belief; reference 1 John 5:13–17.
Understand classical design argument as used by Christians; Romans 1:18–24. Understand divergent interpretations of what design implies about God; Christian responses to atheist/Humanist objections.
Understand cosmological argument for God and its use by Christians; include Aquinas’ First Three Ways; divergent interpretations; Christian responses to atheist/Humanist objections.

Understand Christian teaching on raising children in faith (Proverbs 22:6); features of Christian upbringing and why may lead to belief; Christian responses to atheist/Humanist arguments that upbringing may lead to rejection of God.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living the Christian Life (same as 1B living)
Sub_topics.description: Living the Christian Life content identical to Area of Study 1B Section 3 (worship; sacraments; prayer; pilgrimage; festivals; mission; local and worldwide church; Christian Aid).

Understand Christian teaching on human rights: nature/history/purpose; why Christians support human rights; Proverbs 14:31. Compare divergent Christian responses including situation ethics; respond to non-religious arguments about human rights.
Understand Christian attitudes to equality: causes/problems of inequality and solutions; Christian teaching including Galatians 3:23–29.

Understand Christian attitudes to religious freedom including CCC 1738 and 1747; Church response to multi-faith society; benefits/challenges; responses to atheist/Humanist arguments against aspects of religious freedom.
Understand Christian responses to prejudice and discrimination and problems caused; explain why discrimination against religions is wrong with Galatians 2:1–10.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Racial harmony (John 13:34; Desmond Tutu; situation ethics)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Christian teaching on racial harmony including John 13:34 and links to situation ethics. Know work/teachings of Desmond Tutu; benefits of multi-ethnic society for Christians.
Understand Christian teachings/responses to racial discrimination and why it causes societal problems; Acts 17:22–28.
Understand Christian attitudes to distribution of wealth/opportunity in UK/world; Christian teaching on social justice including Matthew 25:31–46; Church action; links to situation ethics.
Understand Christian teaching on poverty (absolute/relative) and causes; Christian teaching on wealth/poverty including Matthew 25:31–47; links to virtue ethics.

Sub_topics.description: Beliefs content identical to Area of Study 1C Section 1 (Six Beliefs; Five Roots; Allah; Risalah; Kutub; Malaikah; al-Qadr; Akhirah).
Understand revelation as proof of Allah: Qur’an as revelation; direct revelation (Surah 34:46–50) or through messenger; divergent understandings of what revelation shows about Allah’s nature.

Understand visions: nature/importance in Islam; Qur’anic example Surah 19:16–22. Explain why visions may lead to belief and Muslim responses to atheist/Humanist hallucination objections. Understand divergent interpretations of what visions show about Allah in Sunni, Shi’a and Sufi Islam.

Understand miracles: nature/importance; Qur’an as miracle (Surah 17:84–89); other examples. Explain why miracles may lead to belief and Muslim responses to atheist/Humanist scientific objections; divergent interpretations of what miracles show about Allah.

Understand religious experience: nature; Surah 2:118. Understand divergent views of religious experiences in Sunni, Shi’a and Sufi Islam. Explain Muslim responses to atheist/Humanist claims that religious experiences are not proof of Allah.
Understand design argument in Islam for Allah’s existence and what it shows about Allah’s nature; Surah 2:164. Explain divergent views and Muslim responses to atheist/Humanist objections.

Understand cosmological argument in Islam: Surah 79:27–33; kalam argument in writings of Al-Ghazali (Kitab al-lqtisad fil’ltiqad). Explain what it shows about Allah’s nature; strengths/challenges; Muslim responses to atheist/Humanist objections.
Understand issues raised by suffering for belief that Allah is compassionate; Surah 1. Explain why problem may lead to rejection or doubt and how it functions as philosophical argument.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Solutions to suffering: life as test; prayer; charity (Surah 2:151–177)
Sub_topics.description: Understand practical and philosophical solutions to suffering in Islam: Qur’anic (Surah 2:151–177), life as test, prayer, charity. Understand divergent views on success of solutions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living the Muslim Life (same as 1C living)
Sub_topics.description: Living the Muslim Life content identical to Area of Study 1C Section 3 (Ten Obligatory Acts; Shahadah; Salah; Sawm/Laylat al-Qadr; Zakah/Khums; Hajj; Jihad; Id festivals and commemorations).

Understand Muslim teaching on human rights: nature/purpose; why Muslims support human rights; Surah 5:8. Understand divergent Muslim responses including situation ethics; problems human rights might cause for Muslims; respond to non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments.

Understand Muslim attitudes to equality: causes/problems of inequality; Hadith example Sahih al-Bukhari 56:681. Understand divergent Muslim teachings/practices reflecting equality; possible Islamic solutions and reasons Muslims support them.

Understand Muslim attitudes to religious freedom: Surah 2:255–257; divergent Muslim responses to multi-faith society; benefits/challenges; respond to atheist/Humanist arguments against aspects of religious freedom.
Understand Muslim teaching on prejudice/discrimination and problems caused; Surah 49:13; links to situation ethics; why discrimination against religions is wrong.
Understand Muslim teaching on racial harmony; ways Muslims have worked for racial harmony including Final Sermon of Muhammad; link to ethical theory; benefits of multi-ethnic society for Muslims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Racial discrimination: Malcolm X and Surah 49:13
Sub_topics.description: Understand Muslim teachings on racial discrimination and societal problems; Surah 49:13. Understand divergent Muslim responses using life/teachings of Malcolm X as example.

Understand Muslim teaching on social justice: distribution of wealth/opportunity in UK/world; Surah 7:155–157. Understand ways Muslims work for social justice; links to situation ethics and responses.

Sub_topics.description: Beliefs content identical to Area of Study 1D Section 1 (Buddha’s life; dhamma; Noble Truths; human life; ethics).
Understand Buddhist teaching that there is no need for a personal God; reference Devadaha Sutta. Explain implications of lack of belief in personal God for Buddhist life today.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Realm of Gods (devas) and Wheel of Life (Śūraṅgama Sūtra)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist understanding of devas/Realm of Gods and difference between a personal God and devas; reference Śūraṅgama Sūtra Section 9 Chapter 11. Understand Wheel of Life symbolism; divergent attitudes to importance in Theravada vs Mahayana.

Understand enlightenment in Theravada and Mahayana; example of Buddha (Maha-Saccaka Sutta). Explain why enlightenment is important and its role today. Understand Buddhist responses to atheist/Humanist arguments that enlightenment is illogical or scientifically explainable.

Understand divergent Buddhist teachings about miracles: Buddha’s attitude to supernatural powers (Kevatta Sutta); use as philosophical argument for reality; reasons miracles may or may not be important; differences Theravada/Mahayana; responses to scientific objections.

Understand Buddhist prayer: nature/importance; example Avalokitesvara mantra ‘Om padme hum’; reasons for praying (metta, sharing merit, opening mind to consciousness). Understand divergent views on importance of prayer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Visions (Vajra Sutta; Asanga/Maitreya) and non-religious critiques
Sub_topics.description: Understand visions in Buddhism: Vajra Sutta; vision of Maitreya by Asanga and ‘Five Treatises of Maitreya’. Understand Buddhist attitudes to visions as emptiness/illusion/dreams, message dreams, or mental health. Explain why visions may/may not be important; respond to atheist/Humanist hallucination objections.

Understand Buddhist attitudes to religious experiences: Kevatta Sutta; whether experiences are real or provide knowledge; use as philosophical argument for nature of reality; responses to atheist/Humanist arguments that experiences are not real.

Understand how Buddhist upbringing shapes understanding of reality; features of Buddhist upbringing (Sigalovada Sutta). Understand Buddhist responses to atheist/Humanist arguments that religious upbringing may cause rejection of God’s existence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living the Buddhist Life (same as 1D living)
Sub_topics.description: Living the Buddhist Life content identical to Area of Study 1D Section 3 (meditation; chanting; mantra; places; objects; puja; death rituals; festivals/retreats).

Understand Buddhist teaching on human rights: nature/purpose; why Buddhists support human rights; include upekkha and Declaration of the International Network of Engaged Buddhists: Towards A Buddhist Culture of Non-Violence and Human Rights (May 1998). Understand divergent responses including situation ethics; potential problems; respond to non-religious (atheist/Humanist) arguments.
Understand Buddhist attitudes to equality: causes/problems of inequality; teachings/practices reflecting equality including Lotus Sutra 12; possible Buddhist solutions and reasons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious freedom (Dalai Lama, True Kinship of Faiths Ch.9)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist attitudes to religious freedom including Towards The True Kinship Of Faiths: How the World's Religions Can Come Together Chapter 9 (XIV Dalai Lama). Understand divergent responses to multi-faith society and benefits/challenges; respond to atheist/Humanist arguments against aspects of freedom.
Understand Buddhist responses to prejudice/discrimination and problems caused; links to situation ethics. Explain why discrimination against religions is wrong including Nipata Sutta.
Understand Buddhist teaching on racial harmony; Vaca Sutta; links to situation ethics; benefits of multi-ethnic society for Buddhists.
Understand Buddhist teaching on racial discrimination and societal problems; Dhammapada 129–140. Understand Buddhist responses as shown in life/teachings of XIV Dalai Lama.

Understand Buddhist attitudes to distribution of wealth/opportunity in UK/world; Buddhist teaching on social justice including Sikshasamuccaya 280–281; ways Buddhists work for social justice; links to situation ethics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wealth and poverty (Cula Kammavibhanga Sutta; dana; merit)
Sub_topics.description: Understand Buddhist teachings/responses to poverty causes; Cula Kammavibhanga Sutta; merit and dana; links to situation ethics; divergent teachings and responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Visions: Bhagavad Gita 11 and non-religious critiques

Sub_topics.description: Understand Hindu teachings leading some Hindus not to believe in a personal God, including Adi Shankara’s Upadesa sahasri Chapter 1. Explain implications for Hindu life today and divergent views.

Understand Hindu attitudes to religious freedom with Rig Veda 1.164.46 and Bhagavad Gita 4.11; response to multi-faith society; benefits/challenges.

Understand Hindu teachings/responses to racial discrimination; why it causes societal problems; Mahabharata 5.39.

Topics.Strand: Assessment and command words

Sub_topics.description: AO1: Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of religion and belief including: beliefs, practices and sources of authority; influence of religion/belief on individuals, communities and societies; similarities and differences within and/or between religions and beliefs. Weighting: 50% overall GCSE; each selected paper contributes 25% AO1.
AO2: Analyse and evaluate aspects of religion and belief, including their significance and influence. Weighting: 50% overall GCSE; each selected paper contributes 25% AO2.

Topics.Strand: Assessment and command words

Sub_topics.description: Command word 'State': provide knowledge of religion and belief by recalling factual information. Typical allocation 3 marks; assesses AO1.
Command word 'Outline': provide knowledge of religion and belief by recalling factual information. Typical allocation 3 marks; assesses AO1.
Command word 'Describe': provide an understanding of religion and belief and contrast with that of another. Typical allocation 4 marks; assesses AO1.

Command word 'Explain': (i) 4 marks: provide understanding of an aspect of religion and belief, developed beyond a habitual response. (ii) 5 marks: as above plus reference to one source of wisdom or authority supporting the explanation. Assesses AO1.

Command word 'Evaluate' (12 marks): analyse the statement, consider different points of view, create logical chains of reasoning underpinned by understanding of religion and belief. Make reasoned judgements supported by appraisal of arguments, leading to a justified conclusion. Extended responses must demonstrate a coherent, relevant, substantiated and logically structured line of reasoning. Assesses AO2.
